document_data.mainbody:
'''Memnor''' was the [[giant]] deity of pride and control. He was an ambiguous figure in [[Giant pantheon|the Ordning]], whose tales concerning him were quite disparate with one another. He schemed to usurp [[Annam All-Father]] as the head of the Ordning, but was unsuccessful, or so it was often suspected of by his siblings.

{{Quote|When it comes to Memnor, the wisest policy is the simplest: don't believe a single thing you read.|[[Diancastra]], one of Memnor's siblings.}}
document_data.Description: Ancient depictions of Memnor often portrayed him as wearing a two-faced mask.
document_data.Personality: Memnor was typically described as charming, intelligent, cultured, subdued, clever, and persuasive. His greatest flaw was his strong sense of pride, though he was also said to be deceitful, intensely cruel, and manipulative. Many of the stories within giant society that recounted his exploits emphasized his charisma and manipulative nature.

Worshipers.Beliefs: Those who worshiped Memnor believed that Annam had grown old and weak. They viewed his incompetence as being largely at fault for the fall of [[Ostoria]]. Many considered it their highest duty to be safeguarding the secrecy of Memnor's scheme to one day overthrow Annam. Though when it came to mortal giants who already knew of this scheme and levied accusations against Memnor's priests, they would insist that their god had only the welfare of all giant-kind in mind, wishing to restore them to their rightful place of glory.
Worshipers.Holy Days: Each year the clerics of Memnor would hold three feasts in his honor for the mainstream of giant society. They were also known to gather together with their wyverns every one hundred days atop crags. There they would discuss strategies and at times even receive orders from Memnor himself.
Worshipers.Symbol: Memnor's [[holy symbol]] was a thin black obelisk.

document_data.History:
One myth conflictingly spoke of Memnor as being Annam's twin, rather than his child, and claimed that the reason Annam was so aloof was due to being weakened after defeating Memnor. In most other myths Memnor was portrayed as playing tricks on and infuriating his father, incurring Annam's wrath upon both himself and more often than not his brothers as well.

When Annam eventually exiled himself from [[Gudheim]], Memnor and Grolantor went and convinced their siblings [[Stronmaus]] and [[Hiatea]] that Annam's decree was no longer valid. From that day onward, Memnor and his brother would go on to continually meddle in the affairs of the mortal giants. At times their antics got so bad that Stronmaus and Hiatea felt they had no choice but to intervene and put an end to their games.
